message.content:
cs.SI, cs.DL, cs.IR, cs.CY, cs.SD 

The paper is concerned with modeling the distribution of citations to scientific papers, which is a topic that falls under several sub-categories of computer science. Specifically, the paper uses a large dataset on citations to scientific papers published between 1998 and 2002 drawn from Scopus, which suggests that it may be relevant to the sub-category of cs.SI (Social and Information Networks). Additionally, the paper compares the power-law model with a number of alternative models using a likelihood ratio test, which suggests that it may be relevant to the sub-category of cs.DL (Digital Libraries). The paper also discusses theories implying that the most highly cited scientific papers follow certain distributions, which suggests that it may be relevant to the sub-category of cs.IR (Information Retrieval) or cs.CY (Computers and Society). Finally, the paper's focus on modeling distributions of citations to scientific papers may also make it relevant to the sub-category of cs.SD (Software Development).
